repnme.cdata!:
Central Africa - BEAC Regional Payments
            System Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Bank of Central African
            States (BEAC) Regional Payments System Project for Central
            Africa were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: payment systems are technically complex and can
            take a long time to implement. The projects require Bank and
            Government teams with specialized skills both in designing
            the project and throughout supervision. Because of their
            technical elements these projects can take time to implement
            and the Bank norm of four years for project disbursements
            may be too short. Projects covering all countries of a
            regional monetary union are the most efficient approach to
            putting in place a payment system. There may also be some
            advantages to the regional approach in upgrading payments
            systems for economic groupings that do not have a single
            central bank. The capacity in financial management and
            procurement should be in place before the startup of the
            project. This applies to all projects, but it is
            particularly important for technically complex ones and
            those to be implemented by institutions which have no prior
            experience in Bank projects. The delays in putting in place
            the team at BEAC delayed the startup of the project.

5084932.majtheme: Rule of law,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Central Africa - BEAC Regional Payment
            System Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The BEAC Regional Payment System Project
            for Central Africa aims at improving the efficiency and
            security of the payment system in the Central African
            Economic and Monetary Union. The project has eight main
            components. The Global Project Management component
            coordinates and implements the reform process, providing
            stakeholders with all needed information, communication, and
            training programs. The Electronic Bulk Payment Clearing
            Systems component manages the exchange and clearing process
            of bulk payments transactions, including the transformation
            of paper instruments into elctronic data. Identical
            electronic clearing systems will be installed in each
            country. A Real Time Gross Settlement mechansim (RTGS)
            enables instant and final irrevocable settlement of
            individual large value and other time criticial
            transactions, among other activities. The Inter Bank Card
            System served by a dedicated network infrastructure includes
            a pre-paid system for the poor in payment for their
            consumption of water and electricity. A Payment Risk
            Management System collects all informaton regarding payment
            incidents for individuals and companies, enabling a better
            control over unreliable customers' operations, and
            providing access to critical information to credit
            institutions and banks. Telecommunications infrastructure
            ensures high-quality, low-cost transfers of data and payment
            transactions among all locations. The project also has legal
            framework and training program components.
